photo.title: Montezuma's Castle

photo.description: Montezuma Castle National Monument, located in Arizona, features well-preserved cliff dwellings. They were built and used by the Pre-Columbian Sinagua people around 1400 AD. When European Americans discovered them in the 1860s, they named them for the Aztec emperor of Mexico Montezuma II, due to mistaken beliefs that the emperor had been connected to their construction.
photo.tags: montezuma castle montezumacastle arizona indian nativeamerican cliff dwelling
photo.title: Montezuma Castle

photo.tags: montezumascastle arizona archaeology cliffdwelling nationalpark
photo.title: dwell

photo.description: "Montezuma Castle National Monument, located near Camp Verde, Arizona . . . features well-preserved cliff dwellings. They were built and used by the Pre-Columbian Sinagua people around 700 AD. Several Hopi clans trace their roots to immigrants from the Montezuma Castle/Beaver Creek area. Clan members periodically return to their former homes for religious ceremonies. When European Americans discovered them in the 1860s, they named them for the Aztec emperor of Mexico Montezuma II, due to mistaken beliefs that the emperor had been connected to their construction . . .The reasons for abandonment of their habitation sites are not yet known, but warfare, drought, and clashes with the newly-arrived Yavapai people have been suggested. The five-story stone and mortar dwellings contain 20 rooms and once housed about 50 people. A natural overhang shades the rooms and shelters them from rain. Another part of the cliff wall bears the marks of an even larger dwelling, which has not survived. The dwellings and the surrounding area were declared a U.S. National Monument on December 8, 1906. The National Monument was listed on the National Register of Historic Places on October 15, 1966.[2]" From Wikipedia Here it is from a little farther away farm5.static.flickr.com/4049/4368893065_fe8f42ff5b_b.jpg Matt Gilmore and I stopped here on our way from the Grand Canyon to Phoenix and Sky Harbor for his flight to TBS at Quantico. I stopped so that he could joke that he had seen the Halls of Montezuma. We had intermittent rain. This is just north of Camp Verde and a little south of Sedona to the east of I-17. You go by the Cliff Castle Casino to get here.
photo.tags: alhikesaz azhike arizona montezumacastle nationalpark sinagua ruins nativeamerican hiking hike hikes nationalmonument nationalregisterofhistoricplaces montezuma castle campverde アリゾナ州 arizonamemoryproject
photo.title: Montezuma Castle National Monument

photo.description: "Montezuma Castle National Monument, located near Camp Verde, Arizona . . . features well-preserved cliff dwellings. They were built and used by the Pre-Columbian Sinagua people around 700 AD. Several Hopi clans trace their roots to immigrants from the Montezuma Castle/Beaver Creek area. Clan members periodically return to their former homes for religious ceremonies. When European Americans discovered them in the 1860s, they named them for the Aztec emperor of Mexico Montezuma II, due to mistaken beliefs that the emperor had been connected to their construction . . .The reasons for abandonment of their habitation sites are not yet known, but warfare, drought, and clashes with the newly-arrived Yavapai people have been suggested. The five-story stone and mortar dwellings contain 20 rooms and once housed about 50 people. A natural overhang shades the rooms and shelters them from rain. Another part of the cliff wall bears the marks of an even larger dwelling, which has not survived. The dwellings and the surrounding area were declared a U.S. National Monument on December 8, 1906. The National Monument was listed on the National Register of Historic Places on October 15, 1966.[2]" From Wikipedia Here it is from closer farm5.static.flickr.com/4068/4368893721_73067aefa8_b.jpg Matt Gilmore and I stopped here on our way from the Grand Canyon to Phoenix and Sky Harbor for his flight to TBS. We had intermittent rain.

photo.title: Montezuma Castle National Monument

photo.description: Montezuma Castle National Monument, located near Camp Verde, Arizona, in the Southwestern United States, features well-preserved cliff dwellings. They were built and used by the Pre-Columbian Sinagua people around 1400 AD. View On Black

photo.description: Quite the place, and so old. 1200's.
photo.tags: canon 40d sigma 18200os zion2010 montezumascastle arizona
photo.title: Montezuma's Castle

photo.description: The "castle" was started about 900 years ago, and abandoned about 600 years ago. Imagine climbing ladders every day to get in and out. On December 8, 1906, President Theodore Roosevelt celebrated the passage of the Antiquities Act by declaring four sites of historic and cultural significance as our nation's first National Monuments. Among these was Montezuma Castle, which the President identified as a place "of the greatest ethnological value and scientific interest." Although very few original artifacts remained in the structure due to intensive looting of the site, Roosevelt's decision assured the continued protection of one of the best preserved prehistoric cliff dwellings in North America. Montezuma Castle National Monument quickly became a destination for America's first car-bound tourists. In 1933, "Castle A", a 45-50 room, pueblo ruin was excavated, uncovering a wealth of artifacts and greatly enhanced our understanding of the Sinagua people who inhabited this riparian "oasis" along Beaver Creek for over 400 years. Early visitors to the monument were allowed access to the structure by climbing a series of ladders up the side of the limestone cliffs. However, due to extensive damage to this valuable cultural landmark, public access of the ruins was discontinued in 1951. Now, approximately 350,000 people a year gaze through the the windows of the past during a visit to Montezuma Castle. Even 600 years after their departure, the legacy of the Sinagua people continues to inspire the imaginations of this and future generations.
photo.tags: canon 40d sigma 18200os zion2010 montezumascastle arizona
photo.title: Montezuma's Castle
